58 EUGIPPIUS

CHAPTER XIII

NEAR a town called Juvao,1 they went into the church one summer day to celebrate the evening service, but found no fire for lighting the lamps. Unable to elicit a blaze in the usual way, by striking stones together, they were so long delayed in striking iron and stone 2 that the time of the evening service was passing. But the man of God kneeled on the ground and prayed earnestly; and soon, in full view of three clerics who were present at the time, the taper which Saint Severinus held in his hand was lighted.³ By its light the sacrifice of eventide was completed in the custo- mary manner, and they returned thanks to God in all things. ³ A similar miracle is related of Alveus‚ or Alneus, a Gallie saint of the sixth century. “ One night he arose for the early morning vigils, and entered the church with the rest of the brethren. They found that the lights which usually burned there were out. Saint Alveus kneeled in prayer. The disciples searched for a light; but they could find no fire. The hour was already late, and the disciples reminded the saint of the lateness of the hour. Presently he rose from prayer, and made the sign of the cross above the waxen taper. The taper was kindled instantly through the excellence of God and the merits of the saint, and gave a splendid light for all who were in the building.⁷’ Acta Sanctorum, September, iii (1750), p. 808.
